newsitem.title: GERMANY: GERMAN CALL MONEY EASES AFTER BUBA INJECTS FUNDS.
newsitem.headline: GERMAN CALL MONEY EASES AFTER BUBA INJECTS FUNDS.

text.p: German call money rates eased to 3.08/3.10 percent on Wednesday after the Bundesbank injected a net 400 million marks into the money market with its repo allocation.
The prevailing rate on Tuesday had been 3.125 percent.
Dealers had expected the Bundesbank to inject up to three billion marks on Wednesday but said market conditions appeared to have warranted a smaller injection.
Dealers said data for Tuesday showed liquidity had risen. Also, banks were more ready to sell cash after the Bundesbank set this week's tender at a steady fixed rate of 3.00 percent.

"Banks have changed their behaviour," one money dealer said. "After the Bundesbank made liquidity available at three percent for a further 14 days those banks that have hoarded money are more willing to put funds on the market."

Before Tuesday, when the Bundesbank set this week's tender at three percent, banks had withheld funds from the market because they thought the Bundesbank may signal it wanted a higher repo rate in defence of the mark.
But Tuesday's announcement allayed those fears and banks' deposits at the Bundesbank -- a measure of market liquidity -- rose sharply to 41.0 billion marks from 39.7 billion.
The average for the month through Tuesday rose to 39.8 billion marks from 39.7 billion. Lombard borrowings were negligible.
The Frankfurt Interbank Overnight Average (FIONA) was 3.12933 percent on Wednesday, down from 3.14867 percent on Tuesday.
